title: Reserve provides a natural oasis within the chaotic region of Naples
text:
Reserve provides a natural oasis within the chaotic region of Naples Occasional guideposts describe the flora and fauna of Astroni Crater Nature Reserve in Agnano, Italy. Steven Beardsley/Stars and Stripes Lago Grande, or great lake, is one of the attractions at Astroni Crater Nature Reserve in Agnano, Italy, near Naples. Directions : The Astroni Crater Nature Reserve (Cratere degli Astroni): Via Astroni agli Agnano, 468-80125 Naples. Take the Agnano exit from the Naples bypass (Tangenziale). At the first roundabout, take the first exit, which leads up the crater side. Follow this road past several large retaining walls painted with murals and to the next roundabout. Take the second exit here, driving past the parking lot of the Hotel Miravalle and continuing on the road. Astroni’s entrance is 600 meters away; the parking area is off a bend in the road. 
Times : Open Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays throughout the year, except New Year’s Day, Easter, the Monday after Easter and Dec. 25 and 26. Gates open at 9:30 am. They close on Fridays and Saturdays at 2:30 p.m. in the winter and 3:30 p.m. in the summer. They close on Sundays at 3:30 p.m. in the winter and 6:30 p.m. in the summer. Entry is permitted up to an hour and a half before closing time. 
Costs : Entry costs 6 euros for adults, 4 euros for ages up to 14 and over 65. With a reservation, groups of 10 or more can pay 8 euros for entrance and a tour of the park. 
Information : Phone: (+39) 081-588-3720, email: oasiastroni@wwf.it , website: wwf.it/oasi/campania/ cratere_degli_astroni 
— Steven Beardsley It’s midmorning on a Sunday near Naples, Italy, and the leaves are rustling in the breeze. Frogs murmur from the shallows while birds cry out as they lift themselves over a glassy blue lake. Welcome to Astroni Crater Nature Reserve, an oasis of beauty tucked within a region better known for chaos. Located about 35 minutes from the Navy’s support site base in Gricignano, Astroni is a weekend retreat for anyone feeling overwhelmed by urban living. Spanning more than 600 acres, the reserve is cradled within a large, extinct crater formed during a surge of volcanic activity 3,600 years ago. The ancient Romans knew Astroni for its thermal springs. Naples’ former French and Spanish rulers would later preserve its forested grounds for hunting. Italy’s unification in the 19th century opened Astroni to all, bringing outside pressures from visitors and the surrounding community of Agnano, a town once famed for its thermal resort. The concrete sprawl of surrounding Agnano reached as far as the crater exterior, which is now dotted with small homes and terraced gardens. Agnano’s sprawl fortunately ends at Astroni’s gates. Italy declared the interior a reserve in 1987 and handed management to the World Wildlife Fund, ruling out future encroachment and restricting access. An entry fee (6 euros) and tight hours keep visitor numbers limited today. And so Astroni’s interior hums along mostly on its own, largely closed off to the outside, save the workers who maintain its trails, some nature classes and birdwatchers. That’s for the best, I decided on my recent visit. Following the main trail down to the crater floor, I quickly left the traffic and graffiti behind to enter a self-contained ecosystem. Here the only roads are the well-maintained walking trails that circle and bisect the crater floor. Instead of concrete, there are oaks, maples and brush thickets; instead of feral dogs, lizards and birds skitter from your advancing footsteps. The perimeter trail leads to the Lago Grande, or the great lake, where a rickety wooden blind sits at one end of the water. The view takes in mallards, kingfishers and the occasional hawk working overhead. Frogs cruise nearby lily pads. Exploring is the best plan for Astroni, and it’s even better with a pair of binoculars, a packed lunch and plenty of water. Maps and guides are available at the reserve ticket office. One of the few places in Naples where it feels possible to be alone, the reserve is a natural oasis in a city otherwise ruled by concrete.
